title: Fundus2Globe: Generative AI-Driven 3D Digital Twins for Personalized Myopia Management
author: Danli Shi (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Bowen Liu (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Zhen Tian (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Yue Wu (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Jiancheng Yang (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Lausanne), Ruoyu Chen (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Bo Yang (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), ..., Mingguang He (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University)
relevance_why: This paper presents a novel generative model for reconstructing 3D eye shapes from 2D images, which may inspire similar methodologies in the audio domain for generating realistic sound profiles based on minimal data.
background: Generating personalized 3D models of the eye based on 2D fundus photographs and metadata to enhance myopia management.
contribution: Fundus2Globe introduces a generative AI framework to solve the challenge of reconstructing 3D ocular shapes from limited 2D data, achieving submillimeter accuracy in eye shape representation.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods relied on costly magnetic resonance imaging for precise eye reconstruction but were limited in accessibility and practicality for routine clinical use.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by integrating a 3D morphable model with a latent diffusion model, enabling high-fidelity 3D reconstruction directly from 2D images.

key_innovation: The model combines established eye morphology with novel generative techniques to simulate realistic and personalized ocular structures efficiently.
real_world_impact: By allowing clinicians to create accurate digital replicas of patient eyes, this tool can significantly enhance the precision of myopia management and treatment planning.
limitations: The paper does not discuss limitations extensively, focusing more on the capabilities of the proposed framework.

new_terms.submillimeter accuracy: **Submillimeter accuracy** refers to a precision level that achieves distinctions smaller than one millimeter, crucial for accurately modeling anatomical features.
new_terms.digital twin: **Digital twin** is a digital replica of a physical entity, allowing for simulation and analysis of its performance over time.
